text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,

and today we're joined
with Juliette Murphy,
the CEO and co-founder from Floodmapp.
Juliette, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about Floodmapp?

- Thank you so much,
Aley, for having me here.
It's an absolute pleasure.

So at Floodmapp, we're
building a safer future.
During the recent flood events,
there is always so many people

that don't have enough
warning or understanding
of how the flood is gonna impact them,

the people, the property,
the critical infrastructure,
especially emergency managers.
So we have a very bold vision
where in the future,

a world in which there's
no lives and no damage
due to flooding.

So we use a mix of
traditional flood modeling
and cutting edge technology,

like machine learning
and big data techniques
to build a super fast, super smart
pinpoint accurate flood model
that can be used to predict flooding
before the event and in real-time.
So unlike traditional models,

ours works really fast,
updates in real-time
so that when an emergency hits
we support those emergency managers

with intelligence before,
during, and after the event.
So it means that they have data
to know the exact properties
to coordinate targeted evacuations
or protect sites and assets,
and know where recovery funding is needed
after a flood event.
- Wow, I mean, with recent events
that have occurred in Australia,

your business is truly
doing a world of good,
including saving the lives of so many
with your cutting edge technology.

And Juliette, I did see
in the news recently
that you just announced a partnership

with Waze and the city
of Norfolk, Virginia.
That's so cool.
Can you share with us
how this opportunity firstly came about

and also the impact the
work is actually having
on the citizens of Virginia?
- Absolutely, so, yeah, we were so excited
to roll out Floodmapp's NowCast model
in the city of Norfolk in Virginia.
So Norfolk, it's a small coastal city
that floods regularly like every month.
Even small amounts of rain
can cause inundation
just due to sinking kind of city,

sea level rise, inundated
storm water infrastructure.
So the city is really not able to cope
with big rainfall events.

Sometimes they get tidal
flooding even on sunny days.

And so the city is really
needing to now adapt

to a changing climate and
these rising sea levels.
In light of that, there's an agency,

a not for profit, Rise
Resilience Innovations

who are working with
innovative technologies,

seeking out businesses who are
working on coastal resilience
and adaptation technology
to help commercialize those ideas
working in partnerships with the cities
like city of Norfolk.
And so they put out a global call

for technology that was able
to help community members
navigate around flooded roads.
And so Floodmapp responded to that call
and we were fortunate to be awarded
and receive funding through this program
selected to implement our technology
as a solution to their flooding.

And so we worked with
the city collaboratively.

And we also worked with Waze,
the traffic routing solution
to integrate our technology with Waze,

to help the public then
get essentially alerts
so that they can know how to navigate

around the flooding in
real-time as it's happened.

And the impact to the
community has been incredible.

So we've seen 100s of
1000s of flood alerts
go out through Floodmapp NowCast
which predicts flooded roads.
And we've seen 1000s and 1000s
of interactions with the public
who's giving thumbs up to confirm
if that flood alert is accurate

which helps us continually
improve that model.

And given that, in the
recent Australian floods,

we saw the majority of lives
were lost on flooded roads
and the same in US,

up to 200 lives per year
are lost on flooded roads.
So there's been big safety implications
for this kind of technology
and really just helping improve

the day to day quality
of life to improve time.
If people need to know
when to pick up the kids from school
or when to get to work,
this technology's gonna help them do that.
- So cool, the partnership with Waze
is so impressive and so impactful.

And Juliette, moving on
from this a little bit.
Why did you choose to invest

in the cloud and in
particular, I guess AWS?
- Yeah, so from day one

we knew we had to build
a cloud based company.

I think part of the
challenge we're solving
with these real time models

is that traditional flood
modeling technologies

have always been very
computationally intensive,

just due to the amount
data pouring into them
and the complex physical equations
that are going into this.
So, we knew cloud was a must

and AWS really supported
us from day number one.

In the early days we
went into a engineering,
sorry, a startup accelerator.
And we were able to get access
to some programs there with some credits.

So, our kind of engineering
team was really proud
to sort of partner with a company
that has a lot of experience
in keeping data safe,

maintaining service
reliability and availability.

That were willing to kind of
work with us collaboratively,

no matter where our
staff are in the world.
So, we work with emergency management.

So we needed a service
that had that reliability,
the trusted brand,
the available kind of redundancy

to serve those emergency
management with confidence
during the flood of it.
So AWS was really a perfect fit
and it's been incredible
kind of going on the journey with them
from when we sort of were just working out
how to do a simple kind of computation
to now sort of running 1000s of services

across kind of 1000s of
machines in real-time.
And that's kind of growing every month.
So that scalability is quite incredible.

- Of course, I mean, most
companies seek a partner
that's reliable and secure,
but in your field, it's so imperative

that your partners can deal
with emergency flood events.

So, I'm really glad that
we haven't let you down
in those difficult times.

And Juliette, I know your
team has worked really closely
with our AWS startup team

that you've just mentioned
along your journey.

So, you mentioned credits
and things like that,
but how has the experience been

working with our startup
teams, specifically?
- So, yeah, really amazing.

I guess one of the
amazing things about AWS
is that it was born from a startup.
So I think inherently AWS gets startups
and in more ways,

than maybe other companies
understands that.
So Amazon, they're a global giant now,

but I guess the thirst
to create something new
is still there.

And so it's been incredible
kind of working with the team
in some hackathons and prototyping

sort of programs to explore
all the different ways
that we can use AWS
and that AWS can develop sort of
and improve future services.

So we use the AWS kind
of forecasting service
to experiment how that can help us
better run machine learning experiments
for new types of models.
And yeah, they've been really supportive

in just helping us explore
what's possible, I guess.

- Well, I love that you
guys remember this about AWS
'cause, yes, of course, you're right.

And to say that thirst
to create and innovate
will never leave us, is so true.

Everyone wants to be in
that startup team at AWS
and help companies build and innovate.
So yeah, absolutely right.
Juliette, to round up this interview,
I did wanna ask you,
what are some future technologies
that you're excited about

that will actually help the
work that Floodmapp's doing?
- Great question, yeah, I don't know.

We're so excited for
the future in general.
We've recently just announced.
We raised a seed round of AU $8.5 million

led by New York based
Union Square Ventures.

And this money is just
vital for us as we grow.
So we are investing in product.
We're investing in scale.
We're investing in our go to market

to really build and
strengthen our technology

in two geographical markets,
Australia and the US.
So, we have a product, we know it works.
It works as a direct feed into GIS systems
for emergency managers
and as an interface to traffic apps.
But the more that we improve our models
and the more that we are able
to sort of scale that technology,
the more we can work

with new sort of industry
verticals and sectors.

So we work a lot with
governments right now
but we're hoping to work

with more critical
infrastructure agencies,
transport agencies within more countries.

So, the future, we really
want to do a lot more

with machine learning
and how we introduce that

to solving the problem
of hydrology forecasting.

And we wanna put this
technology into more hands
of more emergency managers and communities
to build a safer future.
- Thanks so much, Juliette.

I mean, in light of all the
recent floods in Australia

your business value has
definitely been felt
very close to home.
Before, a couple of months ago,

I wasn't aware of how
many floods were happening
all the time, right in my backyard.
So it's really crazy.
It's such an impressive business.
Your impact's remarkable,

and you should be so proud,
again, on the seed round.

So congrats, we cannot wait
to continue working with you.
And if anyone has any questions

please pop them in the
comment section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much.
